questions.text: Which of the following is true about breastmilk jaundice?

options.label: B
options.text: Most of the children require phototherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin more than 10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth

questions.correct_answer: C. Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin more than 10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin more than 10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth Option: C. Exclusive breastfeeding with total bilirubin more than 10mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth Approximately 2-4% of exclusively breastfed term babies have jaundice in excess of 10 mg/ dl beyond third-fourth weeks of life. This is a common pattern, and the jaundice usually resolves without any extra intervention, although the bilirubin levels may remain elevated for a certain time period. However, these babies should be investigated for prolonged jaundice to rule out other causes. A diagnosis of breast milk jaundice should be considered if this is unconjugated (not staining nappies); and other causes for prolongation such as inadequate feeding, continuing hemolysis, extravasated blood, G6PD deficiency and hypothyroidism have been ruled out. Mothers should be advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals and TSB levels usually decline over a period of time.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Breastfeeding should not be continued This is not true. Breastfeeding should not be stopped in cases of breast milk jaundice, as it is generally considered safe and beneficial. This jaundice will typically resolve with continued breastfeeding. Option: B. Most of the children require phototherapy This statement is not true. While some cases of breast milk jaundice may require phototherapy, most cases will fall under physiological jaundice amd hence mostly do not require phototherapy. The jaundice typically resolves on its own over time. Option: D. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia This is not true in the case of breast milk jaundice. Breast milk jaundice is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia typically suggests other causes of jaundice, such as liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary atresia Biliary atresia is not a feature of cystic fibrosis. It is a condition where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to liver damage and jaundice in newborns. It is a separate disease from CF and not typically associated with it.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Nasal polyposis This is a common feature of cystic fibrosis (CF). Individuals with CF often develop nasal polyps due to chronic sinus infections and inflammation. Option: Meconium ileus: It is a classic sign of cystic fibrosis. It occurs when the first stool (meconium) becomes thick and sticky, leading to a bowel obstruction in newborns. It is a hallmark feature of CF. Option: D. Bleeding diathesis: Bleeding diathesis can frequently occur in cystic fibrosis, often due to vitamin K deficiency (due to malabsorption) or complications like liver disease, which can affect clotting factors

questions.text: In children with GBS, all are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: Areflexia of affected limb is a mandatory diagnostic criteria

options.label: B
options.text: Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous immunoglobulin is the first line of management

options.label: D
options.text: Albuminocytological dissociation in CSF is characteristic

questions.correct_answer: B. Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases Plasmapheresis is actually an established treatment for refractory cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome, particularly when patients do not respond to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg). Both plasmapheresis and IVIg are first-line treatments, and plasmapheresis is often used in severe or refractory cases.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A: One of the hallmark features of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is areflexia or hyporeflexia (absence or decreased reflexes) in the affected limbs. Areflexia is considered a key diagnostic feature in GBS. Option: C. IVIg ( Intravenous immunoglobulin ) is considered the first-line treatment for GBS and is used to reduce the severity and duration of the disease, particularly in its acute phase. Option: D. Albuminocytological dissociation refers to an elevated protein level in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with a normal white blood cell count, which is characteristic of GBS. This finding is often used in the diagnosis of GBS.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding paediatric cardiopulmonary resuscitation?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest compression at the rate of 30:2 with 2 rescuers

options.label: B
options.text: Adenosine via interosseous is preferred over other methods

options.label: C
options.text: In chest compression, depth must be at least 1/3rd of AP diameter of the child's chest

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenaline given in dose 0.01 mg/kg iv/io in 1:1000 concentration

questions.correct_answer: C. In chest compression, depth must be at least 1/3rd of AP diameter of the child's chest
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In chest compression, depth must be at least 1/3rd of AP diameter of the child's chest In pediatric CPR, the recommended depth for chest compressions is at least 1/3rd of the anterior-posterior (AP) diameter of the child's chest. For infants, this typically translates to about 1.5 inches (4 cm), and for children, it is about 2 inches (5 cm). This depth ensures effective compression and circulation.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. This ratio (30:2) is correct for adult CPR. However, for pediatric CPR, especially for single rescuer, the recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 for infants and children (up to puberty) when there is one rescuer. But in the case of two rescuers, the ratio for children is 15:2. Therefore, this statement is not fully accurate in the context of pediatric CPR. Option: B. This is not true. While interosseous (IO) access is a valid route for drug administration in pediatric resuscitation when IV access is not available, the preferred method for adenosine administration is intravenous (IV) if access is available. Option: D. This is incorrect. The correct dose of adrenaline (epinephrine) in pediatric resuscitation is 0.01 mg/kg IV or IO for cardiac arrest, but the concentration should be 1:10,000, not 1:1000. The 1:1000 concentration is used for anaphylaxis or severe allergic reactions, not for cardiac arrest. questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Laboratory investigations revealed normal prothrombin time, normal thrombin time, normal partial thromboplastin time, normal platelet count and normal function. Urea clot solubility test was positive. What is the most likely deficient factor in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor XIII The most likely deficient factor in this patient is Factor XIII based on the clinical features and the positive urea clot solubility test. Clinical Presentation : The patient has a history of epistaxis , recurrent rectal bleed , and bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. This type of bleeding is suggestive of a bleeding disorder. Normal Coagulation Tests : The laboratory tests showed normal prothrombin time (PT) , normal partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) , normal thrombin time , normal platelet count , and normal platelet function . These findings suggest that the defect is not related to the classic clotting factors (I-XII), which affect PT and aPTT. Urea Clot Solubility Test : The positive urea clot solubility test is a key finding. This test is specifically used to detect Factor XIII deficiency , as Factor XIII is involved in the final step of coagulation, where fibrin clot stabilization occurs. A deficiency in Factor XIII leads to the formation of unstable fibrin clots that can dissolve prematurely, which would explain the bleeding. Factor XIII deficiency (Fibrin-Stabilizing Factor or Transglutaminase Deficiency) presents with bleeding manifestations, particularly in the neonatal period, and is often associated with umbilical cord bleeding, as well as recurrent soft tissue and mucosal bleeds (such as epistaxis and rectal bleeding). Importantly, the deficiency does not affect routine coagulation tests (PT, aPTT) but is revealed by the urea clot solubility test. Factor XIII deficiency is a rare autosomal bleeding disorder. Factor XIII is a hetero tetramer composed of two catalytic A subunits and two carrier B subunits; activation of factor XIII by thrombin frees the activated A subunits, which covalently crosslink fibrin to increase clot strength and constrain fibrinolysis. The different biochemical roles of the A and B subunits result in distinct clinical manifestations. Inherited deficiencies in the factor XIII A-subunit results in soft tissue, umbilical, surgical, joint, and intracranial bleeding; the latter occurs in about a third of cases. Deficiencies in the B-subunit are associated with mild mucocutaneous and surgical bleeding. Because of its role in stabilizing the fibrin clot, factor XIII deficiency often presents with delayed abnormal bleeding or bruising symptoms where patients may have mild trauma and then present with an excessive hematoma on the following day. Extra hematologic clinical manifestation of factor XIII deficiency includes delayed umbilical cord separation, poor wound healing, and recurrent miscarriages. Treatment for bleeding or major surgery is 20-40 U/kg of factor XIII concentrate. Recombinant A-subunit protein is also available for A-subunit deficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates the primary failure of recovery in an admitted patient with severe acute malnutrition? Failure to regain appetite by day 4 Failure to start to lose edema by day 4 Complete absence of edema by day 10 day Weight gain of less than 5 gm/day from day 20 Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 Failure to regain appetite by day 4 (A): One of the key indicators of recovery in a patient with severe acute malnutrition is the return of appetite. Failure to regain appetite by day 4 suggests that the patient is not responding to treatment as expected. Failure to start to lose edema by day 4 (B): Edema (swelling due to fluid retention) is common in severe acute malnutrition. The expectation is that edema should begin to reduce within a few days of treatment. Failure to see this improvement by day 4 suggests inadequate recovery. Complete absence of edema by day 10 (C): While a patient starting to lose edema may indicate progress in some cases, complete absence of edema by day 10 is a sign of primary failure. Weight gain of less than 5 gm/day from day 20 (D): Substantial weight gain can take longer to set in with severely malnourished children. Failure criteria of SAM management: Failure to gain appetite-day 4 Failure to start to lose edema-day 4 Edema still present-day 10 Failure to gain at least 5 g/day for 3 successive After feeding freely on catch-up diet Look for the cause of failure: Insufficient food given Adjustment of feeding problem Corrected feed given Correct amount offered at required time Being fed adequately at night Child encouraged to eat Leftovers recorded Vitamin or mineral deficiency Unrecognized infections Rumination

questions.text: A 4 year old child was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Influenza virus According to Nelson, parainfluenza virus is the most common viral cause of croup, but other viruses such as influenza, RSV, and adenovirus are also frequently implicated. Influenza virus is often noted as the most common pathogen, especially during flu season. Hemophilus influenza: While this bacterium was once a common cause of respiratory infections in children, it is less common now due to the widespread use of the Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b) vaccine. It is more typically associated with conditions like epiglottitis than croup. Streptococcus pneumonia: This bacterium is a common cause of pneumonia and other bacterial infections but is not a typical cause of croup. Croup is primarily viral in origin. Influenza virus: Influenza virus is indeed one of the most common viral causes of croup, particularly in fall and winter. Other viruses that can cause croup include parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and adenovirus, but influenza virus is the correct choice among the options provided. Diphtheria: While diphtheria can cause severe respiratory symptoms (including a membrane in the throat), it is not a common cause of croup in children.

questions.text: What causes the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in Oxygen After birth, the newborn starts breathing air, which leads to an increase in oxygen levels in the blood. High oxygen levels cause the smooth muscle in the ductus arteriosus to constrict, which leads to its closure. This is the main trigger for ductus arteriosus closure. First Stage (Functional closure): Within 10~15 hours after birth (contraction of smooth muscle & approximation of intima cushion) Second Stage (Anatomic closure): Completed by 2-3 weeks (fibrous proliferation of intima, necrosis of media, hemorrhage in the wall and sealing of the lumen) Ductus arteriosus is closed by 8 weeks in 88% Physiology: Vasoactive substances (acetylcholine, bradykinin, endogenous catecholamine and others) by variations in PH, but CHIEFLY BY O 2 tension and prostaglandins (PGE1, PGE2, prostacyclin, PGI2)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Decrease in CO2 : The normalizing or decrease in CO2 levels after birth (due to the lungs taking over the function of gas exchange) may also play a secondary role in the closure of the ductus arteriosus. However, this effect is less direct than oxygen. Option: C. Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance : After birth, the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases as the lungs fill with air and begin functioning. This reduction in resistance contributes to the closure of the ductus arteriosus by increasing the pressure in the aorta compared to the pulmonary artery, but it is not the primary factor. Option: D. Fall in concentration of catecholamines : While catecholamines (such as adrenaline) have various roles in fetal and postnatal circulation, the fall in catecholamine levels is not directly responsible for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Height for age The correct answer is Height for age.
